Risk Management Plan
Executive Summary
EPA Risk Management Plan 

Executive Summary



A. Accidental Release Prevention Policy

The Town of Ocean City Division of Public Works accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures, and management practices.  All applicable procedures of the US EPA Prevention Program are adhered too.  The Division of Public Works, Risk Management and Emergency Management continue to evaluate and improve its procedures and practices with regards to its accidental release prevention policy.



    The Division of Public Works and Risk Management response policy involves the preparation of response plans, which are tailored to each facility and to the emergency response services available in the community, and is in compliance with the EPA Emergency Response Program requirements.



B. System Description and Regulated Substance Handled

The Ocean City Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) treats the wastewater from the Town of Ocean City and West Ocean City area and discharges the cleaned water to the Atlantic Ocean.  The WWTP is located at 6401 Seabay Drive (64th Street Bayside, west of Coastal Highway) in Ocean City, Maryland.  Disinfection of wastewater is part of the treatment process as required by both the EPA and Maryland Department of the Environment.  After disinfection is completed the chlorine is removed from the effluent stream with sulfur dioxide and the clean effluent is discharged to the Atlantic Ocean via the outfall pipe.  This process is known as de-chlorination.  Both the Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide are regulated by 40 CFR Part 68.



Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide are stored and handled at the WWTP for the disinfection (or chlorination) and De-chlorination processes.  The WWTP chlorination system has a chlorine storage room and a chlorination feed room.  Equipment at this facility includes liquid chlorine containers, liquid chlorine manifolds, chlorine liquid evaporator, chlor

ine gas manifolds, vacuum feed system, chlorinators, safety equipment, chlorine leak detectors and an emergency scrubber system.  The WWTP de-chlorination system has a sulfur dioxide storage room and a sulfonation feed room.  Equipment at the facility includes liquid sulfur dioxide containers, sulfur dioxide gas manifolds, vacuum feed system, sulfonators, safety equipment, sulfur dioxide leak detectors and an emergency scrubber system.



    Typically twelve (12) one-ton containers of chlorine are on site.  Two (2) of the twelve (12) containers are hook-up online.  Eight (8) one-ton containers of sulfur dioxide are usually on site with two (2) of the eight (8) containers hooked-up on line and two (2) of the eight (8) containers hooked-up in stand-by mode.  The WWTP is manned twenty-four hours a day, 365 days a year, by a minimum of two operators capable of responding immediately to either a chlorine or sulfur dioxide leak indicator alarm that may occur.

 

C. Offsite Consequence Analysis

The Offsite Consequence Analysis includes the consideration of two chlorine release scenarios identified as "Worst-Case Release and "Alternative Scenario".  The first scenario is defined by EPA, stating that, "the owner or operator shall assume that the...maximum quantity in the largest vessel, one-ton container, is released as a gas over 10 minutes" due to an unspecified failure.  The alternative Scenario is defined as "more likely to occur than the Worst-Case Release Scenario."  The Offsite Consequence Analysis for the WWTP was conducted with the use of the EPA Risk Management Program Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants.

1. Based on the tables and information provided for a worst-case chlorine or sulfur dioxide release, the following was determined:

i. The "Worst-Case Release Scenario," as defined by EPA, would be for a one-ton container of chlorine or sulfur dioxide to release, as a gas, in a ten-minute period.

ii. The toxic endpoint for the chlorine or sulfur dioxide gas

is 3 ppm.

iii. Passive mitigation can be expected from the building housing the chlorine and the sulfur dioxide, and this will reduce the release rate by 45%.





iv. The distance from the release site to the toxic endpoint is 0.9 miles  (It should be noted that the design of the chlorine and sulfur dioxide feed system [vacuum feed] and the presence of an emergency scrubber system make the possibility of the EPA described "worst-case" scenario practically impossible.





2. The "Alternative (Release) Scenario" was evaluated with the use of the EPA Risk Management Program Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants.  For the WWTP a possible alternative release scenario would be a leak of chlorine gas from a flexible stainless steel tubing (pig tail) connection to a one-ton container.  Such a leak would not have an impact outside the facility boundaries.  The reason for this is because of the active mitigation measures that are in place.  These are:

i. Vacuum feed system and pressure relief vents

ii. Building enclosure providing 45% reduction of the release rate

iii. Chlorine fixed detectors

iv. Emergency scrubber, that ventilates, captures and treats 99.9% of the chlorine gas.



3. The "Alternative (Release) Scenario" for the sulfur dioxide system was evaluated with the use of the EPA Risk Management Program Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants.  For the WWTP a possible alternative release scenario would be a pressure relief valve release of sulfur dioxide through 1/8-inch i.d. sulfur dioxide gas pipe.  Such a leak would not have an impact outside the facility boundaries. The reason for this is because of the active mitigation measures that are in place.  These are:

i. Vacuum feed system and pressure relief vents

ii. Building enclosure providing 45% reduction of the release rate

iii. Chlorine fixed detectors

iv. Emergency scrubber, that ventilates, captures and treats 99.9% of the chlorine gas.



D. The general WWTP accidental release prevention progra

m and chemical-specific prevention steps are based on the Town of Ocean City's program and consists of the following key elements:

1. Highly skilled and trained operators (State licensed)

2. Preventive Maintenance Program

3. Use of State -of-the-art process and safety equipment

4. Performance of a Process Hazard Analysis of equipment and procedures

5. Implementation of an auditing and inspection program

6. Availability of self-contained breathing apparatus to personnel and emergency responders

7. Awareness of the toxic properties and hazards of chlorine

8. The presence of chlorine leak detectors

9. The presence of a emergency chlorine scrubber system



E. Five-Year Accident History

No reportable accidental releases of chlorine or sulfur dioxide have occurred at this facility in the past five years.







F. Emergency Response Program

The WWTP has an emergency response program that is coordinated with the Town of Ocean City Public Works Division, Risk Management and Emergency Management, which include the Public Safety Group (Fire Company, Emergency Medical Services, Police, Coast Guard, Hazardous Materials Team, Emergency Management, Risk Management and Public Works Division).  The program includes an organizational structure of emergency responders and their responsibilities.  Emergency response to a leak at the 15th Street WTP would include selected and trained personnel from all the Public Works and Public Safety Groups.  Emergency-response drills and emergency-response procedure evaluations are conducted annually.



G. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Handling procedures and emergency response procedures will be evaluated annually over the next five years.  Detectors and equipment will be inspected, calibrated and replaced per manufactures recommendations over the next five years.  Routine handling and emergency response training and exercises will be conducted over the time period.
